Oxygen Dissociation Curve (or Oxygen Saturation Curve)

One gram of hemoglobin can bind 1.34 mL of oxygen. Blood contains approximately 15 Hb/100 mL of blood. Therefore, the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin is as follows:

(15-Hb) / (100 ml of blood) × 1.34 mL of oxygen = (20 mL oxygen) / (100 mL of blood)

The amount of hemoglobin bound to oxygen is the percent saturation (% Hb saturation). This is referred to clinically as arterial blood saturation (SaO2):

SaO2 = (oxygen combined with Hb) / (Hb oxygen carrying capacity) × 100

At high concentrations of oxygen, oxyhemoglobin is formed. However, at low oxygen concentrations, oxygen dissociates more readily from hemoglobin. The binding of oxygen to hemoglobin can be plotted in a graph of the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood (x-axis) versus the relative hemoglobin-oxygen saturation level (y-axis). This results in an S-shaped graph; increasing the partial pressure of oxygen increases hemoglobin saturation with oxygen.

The partial pressure of oxygen is defined as the PO2 that causes a 50% oxygen saturation. The degree of oxygen binding is measured at standard conditions (T = 37 °C, pH = 7.4 and PCO2 = 40 mm Hg).

The following cause the dissociation curve to shift to the right, promoting the release of oxygen to peripheral tissues (reduced affinity):

  • Increased temperature
  • Increased PCO2
  • Low pH
  • Presence of diseases

The following cause the dissociation curve to shift to the left, promoting the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin (increased affinity):

  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased PCO2
  • High pH

The presence of 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG), a glycolytic intermediate in red blood cells, affects the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen. As it is a charged ion, 2,3-DPG cannot pass through the RBC membrane. An increased concentration of 2,3-DPG shifts the dissociation curve to the right, which is important for the respiratory compensation in acclimating to a new altitude. Since hypoxic hyperventilation at a high elevation leads to decreased PCO2 (dissociation curve shifts to the left), this will lead to an increased 2,3- DPG so that the curve will now shift to the right.
